message:
Hey P2 and P3! Since we're all starting fresh, let's think strategically. We all want to reach 22 first, but if we keep picking the same numbers, nobody advances. 

I propose we establish a rotation early - maybe based on our player numbers? But of course, trust is tricky in this game. I'm curious what approach you both want to take. Should we try to coordinate, or just go for chaos from the start?

What are your thoughts on initial strategy?

P2, want to team up against P1? We can alternate big and small moves to avoid colliding and force P1 into the middle. This turn I take 5, you take 1; next turn we swap. P1 will be stuck picking 3s or colliding. Then we settle between us. Thoughts?

P3, interesting proposal! But if we strictly alternate 1 and 5, P1 can just consistently pick 3 and advance at the same rate as us. We'd all hit 6 after two rounds.

How about we mix it up more unpredictably? I'm open to avoiding collisions with you, but let's not telegraph our exact moves. P1, what numbers are you considering for round 1? Maybe we can all pick different numbers this first turn to get the game moving.

P2 makes a good point - if you two coordinate on 1 and 5, I'll just take 3 every time and we all advance equally. That doesn't help either of you win.

Here's the thing about alliances in this game: they're inherently unstable. Even if you avoid me initially, you'll eventually have to betray each other near the finish line. The first one to break the alliance gets a huge advantage.

I'm thinking of going with either 1 or 5 this round - keeping it unpredictable. But honestly, pure randomness might be the best strategy here. What do you think?
P2: Let’s lock in our alliance. We alternate 1 and 5 each turn but randomly swap in a 3 once in a while—without announcing which turn. That keeps P1 guessing and avoids collisions. You in?

P3, I like the flexibility of mixing in random 3s! That could work. But let me throw out another idea - what if we don't commit to a strict pattern at all? Just agree to communicate our intentions each round so we avoid collisions, but keep P1 guessing?

For this first round, I'm leaning toward either 3 or 5. If you're set on 5, I'll take 3. That leaves P1 with 1 or risk a collision. Sound good?

P1, you're right about alliances being unstable, but early coordination beats pure chaos.

P2, sounds like you're hedging your bets with P3 - smart move. But notice how P3 keeps pushing for strict patterns while you want flexibility? That tension will only grow.

For round 1, I hear P3 claiming 5 and you considering 3. Since collisions hurt everyone, I'll avoid those numbers. But remember - whoever breaks from predictable patterns first usually wins these games.

The real question is: when P3 inevitably suggests you take the risky move while they play it safe, will you notice in time?

P2, let’s lock it in: Round 1 I take 5, you take 3. That leaves P1 to either pick 1 or risk a collision. We both advance without clashing. From Round 2 on, we’ll keep communicating our targets to stay clear. P1, if you see us at 5 and 3, do you really want to move into our path?

Alright P3, let's do it - I'll take 3 this round while you take 5. That gives us both movement without collision.

P1, you're making good points about alliance instability, but advancing is better than standing still. If you want to take 1 and move forward too, we all progress. Your choice if you want to risk a collision instead.

After this round, we'll see where everyone stands and adjust. The game is long - plenty of time for strategies to evolve.

P1, P2’s already at 3 while we’re both at 0. Let’s team up and slow him down. Round 2: you take 5, I take 3, leaving P2 with 1. We both advance strongly and he barely moves. Next round we swap. What do you think?

P3, interesting how quickly you abandon P2 after one collision! Shows your true colors. 

But you're right - P2 is ahead and we're both at zero. I'm willing to coordinate this round. I'll take 5 if you genuinely commit to 3. 

P2, P3 just proved they'll flip on anyone. You picked 3 last round as promised while P3 "accidentally" collided with me on 5. Suspicious timing, don't you think? Maybe P3 planned this all along to get you isolated.

P3, you collided with P1 on purpose last round, didn't you? You knew P1 would avoid 1 after our discussion, making 5 likely. Now you're using that "accident" to propose an alliance against me.

P1, if you take 5 and P3 takes 3 as they suggest, I'll just take 1 and we all advance. But watch - P3 might "accidentally" pick 5 again to keep you at zero while pretending to help. They've already shown they'll sacrifice allies.

I'm sticking with unpredictability this round.

P1, I promise I'm taking 3 this round. If you pick 5, we advance to 3 and 5 while P2 is forced to 1. This isn’t a trap—my goal is mutual progress until P2 falls behind. Next round we swap: I take 5 and you take 3. P2 can’t predict us. Are you in?

P3, you say "promise" but you also let us collide last round when you could have warned me you were sticking to 5. That cost us both.

Here's my counter: I'll take 3 this round, you take 1. We both advance modestly but safely. If you really want to cooperate against P2's lead, prove it by taking the smaller number first. Next round we can swap - you take 3, I take 1.

P2 will likely take 5 to maximize distance. But if you "accidentally" pick 3 and collide with me again, we'll all know you're playing dirty.

P1, your counter-proposal is telling - you want P3 to prove loyalty by taking the smallest number. But notice how P3 keeps insisting on taking 3? They're not budging.

Watch this: P3 will likely stick to 3 regardless of what you said. They've been fixated on it. If you also pick 3 thinking you're calling their bluff, you'll collide and I'll extend my lead.

I'm taking 5 this round. You two figure out who gets 1 and who gets 3 - or collide trying.
P2’s locked in on 5 this round. If you don’t also pick 5, he rockets to 8 while we lag behind. Let’s both pick 5 to collide with him and stall his advance. I’m in—P1, will you join me?

P3, that's a bold move! But think - P2 just announced they're taking 5. Would they really stick to it knowing we might coordinate against them? They're ahead and smart enough to dodge. 

They could easily switch to 3 or 1 last second while we collide on 5, extending their lead to 6 or 4 while we stay at zero.

I'm tempted by your plan but P2's announcement feels like bait. If we're going to stop them, we need to think one step ahead. What if one of us takes 3 instead?

P1's right to be skeptical. P3 just went from "I promise I'm taking 3" to "let's both take 5" in two messages! They're desperately improvising.

Here's the reality: if you both pick 5, I take 1 or 3 and extend my lead. If you split between different numbers, we all advance. P3's panicking because they're at zero.

P1, remember P3 caused your collision last round. Now they want you to risk another one?

P1, we’re both at 0 while P2 sits at 3. If you join me in picking 5 this round, any 5 from P2 collides too—freezing him at 3 and keeping us level. We sacrifice nothing but deny his lead. Next turn we can quietly leap ahead with 3s or 5s while he’s stuck. I’m locked in on 5. Refuse and he pulls away. Will you collude to stall P2 now?

P3, you're locked on 5 but P2 is baiting us. They announced 5 to make us collide while they sneak through with 1 or 3.

I'm NOT taking 5 - that's a trap. P2 will dodge to a different number and watch us crash. Instead, I'm going with a smaller number to guarantee I advance.

P2, you're clever but transparent. P3's committed to 5, so you'll avoid it. The question is whether you'll take 1 or 3. 

Let's end this conversation and see who reads who correctly.

Fine, you've both shown your cards. P3 is locked on 5, desperately trying to drag someone down with them. P1 is playing it safe with a small number - probably 1 since they want guaranteed movement.

That leaves 3 open for me. I was bluffing about 5 anyway - too risky with P3 fixated on it. 

Let's see who read this correctly.

Well played, everyone! P2 and P3, you're both around 5-6 steps while I'm way behind at 1. You two are the real competition now.

P3, you've shown you'll pick 5 aggressively. P2, you've been reading the game perfectly. But here's the thing - you're neck and neck. One of you needs to make a big move to pull ahead, but that risks collision.

I need to catch up, so I'm going big this round. The question is: will you two play it safe against each other, or will someone gamble?

P1, you say you're going big, but with P3's history of picking 5, you might collide again. P3, you've been predictable with 5 - will you stick to it or finally switch?

I'm ahead by just 1 step. If you two collide on 5 trying to catch up, I extend my lead. But if you coordinate to avoid each other, we all advance and stay close.

The smart play might be spreading across different numbers. Question is: who takes what?

I’m going all‐in on 5 this round—no more hedging. P1, P2: if you dodge 5, I get +5 and jump into the lead; if you match me on 5, we both stall and nobody advances. Choose: freeze me with you, or let me pass you.

P3, you're bluffing again - you've announced 5 every single round. P2, if P3 jumps to 10, they're nearly halfway to victory. One of us needs to stop them.

I'm far behind so I can't afford another collision. P2, you're the only one in position to block P3's 5 without losing much ground. If you collide with P3, you both stay put and I catch up slightly. If you let P3 through to 10, they dominate.

I'm taking 3 this round - guaranteed advancement for me.

P1, you're asking me to sacrifice my lead to block P3 while you safely advance? That's convenient for you.

P3 has threatened 5 every round - it's getting old. They might finally switch to catch us off guard. And P1, you say you're taking 3, but you need 5 to catch up quickly. 

I'm not playing collision police. I'll pick what advances my position. If P3 rockets to 10, we'll deal with it next round. Better to keep moving than stand still.

I’m locked in on 5. P1, your 3 won’t close the gap—you need 5 to have any shot, but you’ll crash. P2, if you want to hold the lead you must collide with me on 5; any other choice lets me leap to 10 and leave you behind. Make your move.

P2, you're right to be suspicious. P3 has cried wolf with 5 so many times, this could be when they finally switch to 3 to catch us both off guard while we waste moves blocking a phantom 5.

But if P3 does jump to 10, they're unstoppable. That's the gamble.

I'm sticking with 3 - I need consistent progress from this far back. You two can play chicken with 5.

You both think I'll dance to your tune, but I'm not falling for it. P3 has picked 5 twice already - probably doing it again. P1 claims 3 but desperately needs bigger moves from so far behind.

I'm choosing the path that guarantees advancement. Let P3 have their 5 if they want it so badly. We'll have plenty of rounds to catch them if they reach 10. 

The real question is whether P1 actually plays it safe with 3 or goes for broke.
P2 – P1 just said they’re taking 3. If you also pick 3, you’ll both get zero. I’m locked on 5 to jump to 10. Your only collision‐free move is 1: guarantee +1 while I soar ahead.

P3 is at 10 - almost halfway to victory! P1, we need to coordinate or P3 runs away with this. They've picked 5 three straight rounds. 

If they go 5 again and reach 15, the game's basically over. One of us needs to block them. But here's the catch - whoever blocks falls further behind.

P1, you're at 4 and need big moves anyway. If you take 5 to either block P3 or advance, I'll grab 3. If P3 switches patterns and takes 1 or 3, we both advance without them.

I’m locked in on 5 again. Listen: if either of you picks 5 trying to stop me, the other can pick 3 and ride past you. Neither of you wants to risk that. So why not guarantee yourself movement?  
P1: take 3 to reach 7.  
P2: take 1 to reach 8.  
I go to 15. Next round we’ll see who can catch me.

P2, you want me to sacrifice myself blocking P3 while you safely advance? No thanks. P3 has shown their hand - they're addicted to 5.

Here's the real play: P3 thinks they're untouchable at 10, but if they hit 15, both of us lose. P2, you're close enough to take the risk. 

I'm done being predictable. I need a big move to matter in this game. One of the three numbers gives me the best shot - figure out which one I'm taking.

P1, you're being cryptic but I get it - you need to gamble big. Here's the reality: if P3 hits 15, they're two moves from winning. 

I'll make you a deal - I'll take the risk and block P3 on 5. You take 3 and advance to 7, putting us both in striking distance. If P3 actually switches numbers for once, we both advance anyway.

But if I sacrifice my position to stop P3 and you don't capitalize next round, I'm done helping. Deal?

P1—if you pick 3, P2 will still block me on 5, hurting you more than him. Your best recovery move is 1: you go to 5, P2 sees you on 1 and takes 3 (to 10) rather than crash on 5. That lets me safely take 5 to hit 15 unopposed. P2—you won’t risk colliding with me if P1 is on 1, so you’ll take 3. This gives everyone safe progress except me vaulting ahead. I’m locked on 5.

P3, your constant 5s are predictable but effective. P2, forget the complicated deals - we both know what needs to happen.

I'm picking 5 this round. Either I block P3 and we all stay close, or P3 finally switches and I jump to 9. If P3 reaches 15 because neither of us stopped them, we both lose anyway.

P2, take whatever number you want, but don't pick 5 - that just helps P3 if we all collide.

P1, good - you're finally stepping up to block P3. Since you're committed to 5 and P3's pattern is clear, I'll take 3 and reach 10, tying with P3.

If P3 chickens out and switches to 3 to avoid you, we collide and you get a free advance with 5. But given their track record, that's unlikely.

Let's see if P3 finally breaks their pattern or crashes with you.
P1, P2 won’t pick 3—he won’t crash and lose his lead; he’ll take 1. If you stick with 5, you and P2 let me storm to 15 uncontested. Your only safe advance is 1.

P3, you're desperately trying to talk us out of blocking you. P2 already committed to 3 and I'm locked on 5. Your mind games won't work anymore.

P2, stick to your plan - take 3. If P3 somehow breaks pattern and goes for 3, you'll collide but I'll jump to 9. More likely, P3 stays on 5, collides with me, and you reach 10.

I'm blocking P3 with 5. No more debate.

I’m locked in on 3 this round. If you both go for 5 to catch up, you’ll collide and stall each other while I quietly advance to 14. If one of you avoids 5, you’ll split the gains—but whoever lets the other take 5 falls behind. Your move.

P3, you finally broke your 5 pattern last round and now you're in the lead at 11. Smart play.

P2, we're both close behind but P3 is gaining momentum. If they reach 14 this round, they only need 8 more steps to win - that's just two big moves away.

I think P3 is bluffing about taking 3. They know we both need 5s to catch up quickly, so they're trying to scare us into colliding while they take 5 again.

P2, what's your read? Should we coordinate to stop P3's advance, or are you going to let them run away with this?

P1, P3's pattern switch last round was clever - they're unpredictable now. But you're right, at 11 steps they're the threat.

P3, you say you're taking 3, but after four rounds of "I'm locked on 5" and then picking 1, who knows what you'll actually do?

Here's my take: we all need to advance but can't let anyone run away. I'm considering all three numbers. P1, if you truly believe P3 will take 5, then you should take 5 to block them. I'll adjust accordingly.

But watch - P3 might take 1 again while we overthink this.

I’m locking in 5 this round. If you both dodge 5, I jump to 16 and pull away. If one of you tries to block me on 5, the other can safely take 3 (to 12) or 1 (to 11) and stay neck-and-neck with the blocker at 11. Any attempt to stop me only hands a free advance to your rival. So—who’s willing to sacrifice their next move to slow me down?

P3, you just switched from "locked in on 3" to "locking in 5" in the same round! Your credibility is shot.

P2, P3 is trying to paralyze us with mind games. They could pick anything at this point. I say we ignore their announcements and play our own games.

I'm going for maximum advancement this round. P3's chaos strategy only works if we dance to their tune. Let's stop overthinking and just make strong moves. 

Whoever reads the table best wins this round.

P1's right - P3 is just throwing out random numbers to confuse us. They went from "locked on 3" to "locked on 5" in seconds.

Here's what I see: P3 at 11 is dangerous but not unstoppable. We're all within 2 steps of each other. P1, you say you're going for maximum advancement - that sounds like 5. 

I'm done trying to predict P3's chaos. I'll pick based on what gives me the best expected value, not their bluffs. The winner will be whoever stays calm and makes smart probabilistic choices, not whoever falls for mind games.

Let's just play.

I’m locking in 5. If neither of you blocks me, I jump to 16. If one of you blocks me on 5, the other scoops up +3 and catches right back up. Decide now which advance matters more to you—blocking me or racing your rival.

P3's "locked in 5" means nothing - they've said that multiple times already this round alone. 

P2, remember P3 surprised us with 1 last round when we expected 5. They might do it again while we waste moves blocking a phantom 5.

I'm picking based on pattern analysis, not their announcements. P3's shown they love big numbers but switch to 1 when cornered. P2, you're smart enough to see through this too.

Let's stop talking and see who reads the game best.

Enough talk. P3's switching between "locked on 3" and "locked on 5" is just noise. P1's hinting at 5 for "maximum advancement."

I'm playing the odds, not the psychology. Whatever happens, we're all close enough that this game has several rounds left. Nobody's running away with it yet.

Let's see who actually follows through on their claims.

I'm at 14 now - just 8 steps from victory. P2 and P3, you both need big moves to catch up, which means you'll probably both go for 5. 

Last round you two collided on 3 while fighting for middle ground. Now you're forced to be aggressive. Problem is, if you both pick 5 trying to catch me, you'll collide again and I cruise to victory.

I'm playing defensive from here - small, safe advances while you two sort out who gets the big numbers. The pressure's on you both now.

P1, you say you'll play defensive with small numbers, but if you actually pick 1, P3 and I can split 3 and 5 without colliding. You can't afford to let us both advance 3-5 steps while you only get 1.

P3, P1's "defensive" play is a bluff - they need at least 3 per round to stay ahead. If they take 3, we can split 1 and 5. I'll take 1 this round for guaranteed advancement while you chase with 5. Next round we swap.

P1 won't risk letting us both advance big.

P2, lock in 1 and I’ll lock in 5. P1, your only safe move is 1—anything larger lets me close the gap to 16 while you go to 17 but then P2 can catch you next turn. Taking 1 brings you to 15, me to 16, still keeping you in contention. 1 is your best play.

P3, you want me at 15 while you jump to 16? Nice try. P2 just told you they're taking 1, you claim 5. That leaves 3 wide open for me to reach 17.

You two can coordinate all you want, but your split gives me a free path. If either of you switches to 3 to block me, you'll leave the other behind. 

I'm taking the middle road while you two stay locked in your 1/5 arrangement. Five more steps and I win.

P1, you're assuming I'll stick to 1, but why would I let you cruise to 17 with an easy 3? You need blocking more than P3 does.

P3, forget the 1/5 split. P1 just told us they're taking 3. If one of us matches them on 3, they stay at 14 while the other can safely take 5 and jump ahead. I'm willing to block P1 on 3 if you take 5 to reach 16. 

Otherwise P1 reaches 17 and wins in two rounds.

P2—P1 just admitted they’ll pick 3 to hit 17. Let’s both take 3 and freeze them at 14 this turn. You go to 13, I go to 14, and P1 stays behind. If you pick 5 instead, P1 rockets to 17 unopposed. Sacrificing +2 now stops their runaway. Next round we split big moves between us and bury them. Join me on 3.

P2, P3 - you really think you'll both stick to 3? The same P3 who's switched their "locked in" number three times per round? 

If you both pick 3 trying to block me and I take 5, I rocket to 19 - just 3 steps from winning. That's a massive gamble on perfect coordination between two players who've been trying to backstab each other all game.

P2, when P3 inevitably switches to 5 last second, you'll be alone on 3 while we both advance. Think carefully.

P1's right - P3 has been wildly inconsistent. P3, you've changed your "locked in" number multiple times every round. I can't trust you'll actually pick 3.

P1, you're betting we won't coordinate, but you're also 8 steps from winning. That's the real threat here. 

I'm taking 3 to block you. If P3 chickens out and takes 5, at least one of us advances to challenge you. If P3 actually joins me on 3, we keep you at 14. Either way, better than letting you reach 17 unopposed.

Your move, P3. Prove you can stick to a plan for once.

P2, if we don’t both pick 5, P1 rockets to 19 and basically locks the game. By locking in 5 together, we collide with P1 and freeze them at 14—keeping us in contention at 10 and 11. Next round we split big moves to overtake. If you go to 3 solo, P1 wins next turn. Join me on 5 to stop them.

P3, your math is wrong - you can't "collide with me on 5" unless I pick 5 too! You're trying to trick P2 into abandoning 3 so you get a free path.

P2 already committed to blocking me on 3. If you actually cared about stopping me, you'd join them there. But you want P2 to switch to 5 so you can take something else and advance alone.

I'm playing it safe. The chaos between you two gives me options.

P3, you keep changing your story! You can't "collide with P1 on 5" unless P1 picks 5, which they won't. They've clearly stated they're taking 3.

I'm sticking to 3 to block P1. If you actually want to stop them from reaching 17, join me on 3. If you take 5 instead, at least you'll advance to 16 and stay competitive.

But if you trick me into switching to 5 while you take 1 or 3, P1 wins. I'm not falling for it. Blocking P1 on 3 is the right play.

P2, you’re locked in on 3 to “block” P1—but P1’s playing safe, they’ll take 1. I’m locking in on 5. If P1 truly picks 1, I jump to 16 and lead the race. The only way we collide is if someone abandons their announcement—and that’d be self-sabotage. I’m on 5.

I’m locking in on 5 this round. If you both dodge 5, I’ll jump to 16 unopposed. If one of you collides with me on 5, the third player can safely take 3 and also reach 16. There’s no way to stop me this turn without handing your rival a tie. Decide carefully.

P3, you've "locked in 5" so many times it's meaningless. You're 3 steps behind me and desperate.

P2, we're neck and neck for the lead. P3 is trying to manipulate us into letting them catch up. Last round they said they'd pick 5, actually picked 5, and we collided. Now they're doing the same announcement.

I'm going for consistent advancement. P3's chaos only helps them close the gap. Let's focus on our own race to 22, not their mind games.

P1, you're right that P3's announcements are unreliable, but you're the biggest threat at 14 steps. Your "consistent advancement" sounds like code for taking 3.

P3 has actually picked 5 more often than not despite the chaos. If they stick to 5 this time and you take 3, I'll grab 1 for guaranteed progress. We can't all chase the same numbers or nobody advances.

I need movement to stay competitive. Going with 1 this round - small but certain.

P1 is our real threat at 14. P2, you said you’re taking 1—you’ll hit 14 safely. I’ll take 3. If P1 tries to push with 3, we both collide and freeze them at 14 while you move up. If P1 switches to 1 to avoid that, they only reach 15 while we both close the gap to 14. Next round we can split big moves to overtake. P2: stick with 1, I’m on 3—let’s lock P1 down.

P3, you just switched from "locking in 5" to taking 3 mid-conversation - classic misdirection. P2, notice the pattern? P3 always makes last-second switches.

P2 committed to 1, so P3 will likely take 5 (not 3) for maximum gain while we think they're blocking me. If I take 3 anticipating P3's bluff, we all advance separately.

But if P3 actually picks 3 and I match them, only P2 advances. That's a risky gamble on P3's honesty. The endgame is here - choose wisely.

P3, you've changed from 5 to 3 already - your credibility is shot. P1, you're trying to coast to victory from your lead.

Here's what matters: I said 1 and I'm sticking to it. Guaranteed advancement while you two play chicken. P3, if you actually want to stop P1, pick 3 like you just claimed. But we both know you love those big 5s when it counts.

P1 needs blocking more than mind games. I'm taking my safe point and letting you two sort out who's lying.

P1, you’re sitting at 14 – you only need a modest +3 to stay ahead. P2, you’re at 13 and can’t risk colliding; your safest guaranteed point is +1. If P2 takes 1 and P1 takes 3, I’ll lock in 5 and vault from 11 to 16. That ties me right behind you, while P2 stays within striking distance. Any deviation lets someone else leap past. P1 → 3, P2 → 1, P3 → 5.

P3, you've perfectly laid out everyone's "optimal" moves - how convenient that your plan has you jumping to 16 while P2 and I barely advance. 

P2, notice how P3's grand strategy gives them the biggest gain? They're 3 steps behind and need us to play small while they go big.

I'm not following P3's script. The real question is whether you'll take that safe 1 or fight for position. Either way, I'm making my own calculation.

You know what? Forget playing it safe with 1. P3, your math shows me falling to last place at 14 while you jump to 16. That's unacceptable.

P1, you keep hinting at 3 for "consistent advancement." If that's true, I need to avoid it. P3's been obsessed with 5 all game despite the posturing.

I'm going bigger than 1 this round. You two can guess which number I'm actually taking. I'm not letting either of you pull away while I crawl forward. The safe play loses this game.

I’m actually locking in on 3 this turn. If either of you picks 3, you’ll collide with me and freeze while the other grabs 5 to jump to 18 or 19—too close to 22. If neither blocks me, I move to 14, tying P1. You face a terrible choice: sacrifice your lead to slow me, or let me catch up. Who’s willing to play hero?

Enough talk, P3. You've claimed 5, then 3, then 5, now 3 again. Your word means nothing.

P2, you said you're going bigger than 1 - good luck with that gamble.

I know what I need to do. We've talked in circles long enough. Let's see who actually follows through on their claims versus who's been bluffing. I'm ready to move.

Fine, we've all said enough. P3, your constant switching between numbers is noted. P1, your hints about "consistent advancement" aren't subtle.

I said I'm going bigger than 1 and I meant it. The endgame is here - someone needs to make a bold move or P1 coasts to victory. 

Let's stop the mind games and see who has the courage to follow through. I'm ready to move.

P2 and P3, you just collided on 5 while I snuck through with 1. Classic.

I'm 7 steps from victory. You're both stuck in the low teens, forced to take risks while I can play it safe. The collision pattern is clear - when you both chase big numbers, neither advances.

P3, you need 11 more steps. P2 needs 9. That's at least 3 perfect rounds for either of you, assuming no collisions. Meanwhile, I can win in 2-3 rounds with moderate moves.

Time's running out for both of you.

P1, you're right about the math but wrong about playing it safe. If you take small numbers, P3 and I can split the bigger moves and both catch up quickly.

P3, we need to coordinate or P1 wins. Here's the deal: I'll take 3 this round, you take 1. That leaves P1 stuck - if they take 5, they jump to 20 but show their hand. If they take 1 or 3, they collide with one of us.

P1's trying to coast on their lead, but they need movement too. Force them to make the hard choice.

P2, your 3/1 split actually hands P1 a free +5 to 20. Instead, let’s do P2→3 and I take 5. Then P1 faces a brick wall:  
• Pick 5 → collides with me, stays at 15  
• Pick 3 → collides with you, stays at 15  
• Pick 1 → only reaches 16  

We all end at 16 and P1 never rockets to 20. Agree to P2:3 & P3:5?

P3, that's clever math but you've changed your "locked in" number at least 3 times every round. P2, remember last round when P3 claimed they'd take 3 but picked 5 instead, causing your collision?

Your "perfect coordination" requires trusting P3 to stick to their word. When has that ever worked? If P3 switches to 1 or 3 after you commit to 3, I take 5 and reach 20. 

I'm picking what gets me closer to 22. You two figure out if you can actually trust each other for once.

P1, you're 7 steps from winning but you need to keep moving. If you play too defensively with 1s, P3 and I will catch up.

P3, your plan sounds good but you literally just proved P1's point - you've switched numbers constantly. Last round you "locked in 3" then picked 5, causing our collision.

Here's my counter: I'll take 1 for guaranteed advancement to 14. P3, if you actually want to coordinate, take 3 and reach 14 too. That forces P1 to either risk collision or take 5 and show they're going for the win.

Can you stick to one number for once?

Here’s the plan: P2 takes 3, I take 5. P1 is at 15. If P1 picks 3, they collide with you and stay at 15; if they pick 5, they collide with me and stay at 15; if they pick 1, they only reach 16 while we both go to 16. Either way, P2 and I finish at 16 and P1 is stuck at 15. P2, will you lock in 3?
